description.plain:
Initially working as a burlesque troupe, entrepreneur and artist, Robin Antin, founded “The Pussycat Dolls” and turned them into one of the most prominent girl bands of the 2000s. Seven girls–Nicole Scherzinger, Melody Thornton, Ashley Roberts, Carmit Bachar, Jessica Sutta, Kaya Jones and Kimberly Wyatt–were signed in 2003 to Interscope Records. Their debut single “Sway” was released in 2004 to no success.

The group’s debut album PCD was released in 2005 to huge success, becoming top-five hits worldwide including in the UK Album Charts and the Billboard 200 and has sold nine million copies worldwide. It featured the group’s most popular songs such as “Don’t Cha”, “Stickwitu”, and “Beep”. “Don’t Cha” is one of the best-selling girl group songs of all time and “Stickwitu” earn the girls' a Grammy nomination for Best Pop Performance By a Duo or Group.

After the departure of Carmit Bachar, Doll Domination was released as their second and final album in 2008. It spawned hit singles such as “When I Grow Up” and “I Hate This Part”.

After the group embarked on Doll Domination Tour, they went on a hiatus in late 2009. To this day, The Pussycat Dolls are one of the best selling girl groups of all time, with fifty four million records worldwide and fifteen million albums sold.

Besides their global success, the girl group has faced its fair share of controversy. A previous member, Kaya Jones, likened her time and overall nature of PCD to that of a “prostitution ring”. The accusations included claims of members maintaining sexual relations with music executives, along with people like Scherzinger–based on Jones' claims–taking advantage of such situations to benefit their own career. Even though Jones spoke out, Robyn Antin hit back by branding these allegations as “disgusting, ridiculous lies”.

In 2019, a decade after each group member parted ways, lead voice Nicole Scherzinger confirmed that the girls (apart from Melody Thornton) would be returning with the respective new Instagram account for the group to indicate their comeback.

body.plain:
Initially working as a burlesque troupe, entrepreneur and artist, Robin Antin, founded “The Pussycat Dolls” and turned them into one of the most prominent girl bands of the 2000s. Seven girls–Nicole Scherzinger, Melody Thornton, Ashley Roberts, Carmit Bachar, Jessica Sutta, Kaya Jones and Kimberly Wyatt–were signed in 2003 to Interscope Records. Their debut single “Sway” was released in 2004 to no success.

The group’s debut album PCD was released in 2005 to huge success, becoming top-five hits worldwide including in the UK Album Charts and the Billboard 200 and has sold nine million copies worldwide. It featured the group’s most popular songs such as “Don’t Cha”, “Stickwitu”, and “Beep”. “Don’t Cha” is one of the best-selling girl group songs of all time and “Stickwitu” earn the girls' a Grammy nomination for Best Pop Performance By a Duo or Group.

After the departure of Carmit Bachar, Doll Domination was released as their second and final album in 2008. It spawned hit singles such as “When I Grow Up” and “I Hate This Part”.

After the group embarked on Doll Domination Tour, they went on a hiatus in late 2009. To this day, The Pussycat Dolls are one of the best selling girl groups of all time, with fifty four million records worldwide and fifteen million albums sold.

Besides their global success, the girl group has faced its fair share of controversy. A previous member, Kaya Jones, likened her time and overall nature of PCD to that of a “prostitution ring”. The accusations included claims of members maintaining sexual relations with music executives, along with people like Scherzinger–based on Jones' claims–taking advantage of such situations to benefit their own career. Even though Jones spoke out, Robyn Antin hit back by branding these allegations as “disgusting, ridiculous lies”.

In 2019, a decade after each group member parted ways, lead voice Nicole Scherzinger confirmed that the girls (apart from Melody Thornton) would be returning with the respective new Instagram account for the group to indicate their comeback.

songs.full_title: Buttons (Remix) by The Pussycat Dolls (Ft. Snoop Dogg)
songs.title: Buttons (Remix)

description.plain:
“Buttons” was released as the 4th single from PCD. This song is a pop, R&B, hip-hop song with a Middle-Eastern sound. It’s about Nicole wanting her partner to take her clothes off. The song managed to peak at number three on the Billboard Hot 100. It reached the top-five in countries such as Australia, Germany, and the United Kingdom and reached number-one in Austria and in New Zealand.

The single has sold two million copies digitally in the US, which made The Pussycat Dolls become the first female group in digital history to have three singles pass the two million mark there. A music video was released for the single that featured Snoop Dogg, and has been Vevo-certified.

songs.embed_content: Read “Buttons (Remix)” by The Pussycat Dolls on Genius

songs.full_title: When I Grow Up by The Pussycat Dolls
songs.title: When I Grow Up

description.plain:
“When I Grow Up” is the opening track and lead single off of The Pussycat Dolls second album, Doll Domination. The song was their first single following the departure of the group’s longest-standing member Carmit Bachar.  Lyrically, the song speaks about the desire to be famous.

The single peaked at number nine on the US Billboard Hot 100.

The song was originally written for Britney Spears‘ sixth album Circus with the original Theron Thomas R. City demo leaking online and containing lyrics such as:

“My name is Britney and I don’t care what you say.“ “I swear that I was flippin’ at first / When they said I looked like Debbie Gibson / And then I tried to dance like Michael Jackson / But people saw me and started laughing.” “I would dress up like Madonna, would even try to sing like Cyndi Lauper / I would pretend I was a superstar, I never thought me being me would get me that far.”

Spears also filmed a cameo for the music video but was this was cut in the final edit.

songs.embed_content: Read “When I Grow Up” by The Pussycat Dolls on Genius
songs.recording_location: 2nd Floor Studios (Los Angeles) & Chalice Recording Studios (Los Angeles)

songs.title: Buttons

description.plain: “Buttons” is a song by American girl group The Pussycat Dolls from their debut 2005 studio album “PCD”. The song sold 2 million digital copies in the U.S. alone and the single was certified platinum by early 2007. Buttons also had a music video featuring Snoop Dog and to date the music video has over 600 million views on YouTube. The song peaked at Number 1 in 4 countries, top 10 in 13 different countries, and in the U.S. peaked at top 5 on different Billboard charts including Hot 100.

songs.embed_content: Read “Buttons” by The Pussycat Dolls on Genius

The song peaked at Number 1 in 4 countries, top 10 in 13 different countries, and in the U.S. peaked at top 5 on different Billboard charts including Hot 100.
